Such a decision would have detrimental economic effects on her life, already compromised by the inability to earn a living and lack of control over material resources.
Tensions between marital partners generally lead to marginalization and humiliation (“haraam es pusi”), which is considered as a “moral” sanction against the violating party.
3) In Ougadougou, traditional polygynous marriages are frequently celebrated among women. Often, in the same family, one woman marries the first husband of another woman, making her his “second wife”. Women think of their sisters-in-law as “second mothers”, and simply consider the other wife a “second daughter” who, eventually, will be “second mother-in-law”. This creates considerable intra-household tensions, but the majority of women resists enacting demands to overturn those situations. Disagreements between two sisters-in-law may provoke manipulation of the household, violence, harassment, marginalization, etc.
Implications of the overall findings
In terms of policy and programmes, it is puzzling that after almost 30 years of Human Rights
Covenant Assembly conventions (including three conventions prohibiting violence against women, which are ratified by all developing countries, including Niger) and a decade of the Beijing
Platform for Action, perceptions of the ideal or the desirability of violence persist in the Sahel.
